item.title: Marine Le Pen’s Anti-Islam Message Gains Influence in France
item.description: The leader of France’s far-right National Front party has pushed the main center-right party toward a stronger anti-immigrant stance after Friday’s attacks.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Second Suspect Is Sought in Paris Attacks
item.description: The police continued their pursuit of one fugitive, Salah Abdeslam, while a French official said that the authorities were looking for an accomplice.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Mourners on Tuesday reflected in the bullet-pierced glass of Le Carillon, the scene of one of the attacks in Paris.

item.title: After Paris Attacks, Waiting for Shopping and Culture to Come Back to Life
item.description: In other cities hit by terrorist attacks, effects on commerce have been short-lived. Will the French capital — and the broader eurozone — be different?
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY, JACK EWING and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: A quiet street in Paris in the wake of the terrorist attacks.

item.title: Israel Outlaws Northern Branch of Islamic Movement
item.description: In an effort to quell a recent wave of violence, the Israeli security cabinet said it had outlawed the northern branch of the group, accusing it of collaborating with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The offices of the northern branch of the Islamic Movement in Israel. The Israeli security cabinet announced on Tuesday that it had outlawed the group.

item.title: Guinea, Last Nation With Ebola, May Soon Be Declared Free of Virus
item.description: A 3-week-old girl now recovering could be the final patient in an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, overwhelmingly in West Africa.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Doctors Without Borders health worker held a 3-week-old girl, Nubia Soumah, the last known Ebola patient in active treatment in the world, this month at an Ebola treatment center in Conakry, Guinea.

item.title: Romanian Parliament Approves New Government
item.description: The new cabinet of Dacian Ciolos, nominated as prime minister in response to accusations of government corruption and inaction, includes ministers with experience at home, abroad and in business.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: World Briefing: First Same-Sex Marriage Ceremony Held in Ireland
item.description: Two 35-year-old men were married in a ceremony that is official after Irish voters approved same-sex marriage in a referendum last May.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: China Faces Sharp Questioning by U.N. Panel on Torture
item.description: The pointed questions came as experts with the United Nations challenged China’s commitment to ending torture and governing by the rule of law.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Greece and Eurozone Creditors in Deal to Unlock $13 Billion
item.description: The breakthrough was an agreement to protect the most vulnerable indebted homeowners from foreclosure, while buffering banks from the worst bad loans.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: During a protest in Athens last week a youth wrote "burn it" on the facade of the Bank of Greece building as molotov cocktails burned.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Dayton Keys to Peace
item.description: Empathy and kind words have their place in diplomacy, along with controlled anger and the threat of force.
item.dc:creator: KATI MARTON

item.title: Afghan Jobs Program Aims to Stem Exodus of Young
item.description: The program announced by President Ashraf Ghani, is intended to recreate some of the jobs that disappeared after NATO forces withdrew.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Russia Says Its Jet Was Bombed Over Egypt and Intensifies Syria Airstrikes
item.description: For the first time since the crash two weeks ago, Moscow acknowledged the bombing, and Egyptian officials softened their earlier denials.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Maxim Grigoryev/Russia's Emergency Ministry, Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The crash site of the Russian jetliner in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula in October.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Soccer Fans Celebrate Draw With China
item.description: For many Hong Kong fans, the World Cup qualifier was as much a political contest as an sporting one.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Hong Kong fans chanting slogans before the 2018 FIFA World Cup qualifying match between Hong Kong and China on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Responds to Paris Attacks Through a Domestic Lens
item.description: Along with revulsion, Chinese leaders and many citizens also voiced a more complex mix of expectations and emotions, rooted in rival views of the country’s own problems.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The Oriental Pearl Tower in Shanghai was bathed in blue, white and red, the colors of the French flag, after the attacks in Paris.

item.title: Memo From Pakistan: Pakistan Military Expands Its Power, and Is Thanked for Doing So
item.description: Aided by a new-media publicity campaign, the military has edged aside the civilian government without the messiness or criticism a complete takeover would bring.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Gen. Raheel Sharif, the Pakistani Army chief, in 2013. General Sharif has presided over the country’s armed forces at a time when they are riding high after curbing domestic terrorism and political crime.

item.title: Cease-Fire and Political Transition in Syria Crucial to Defeating ISIS, Kerry Says
item.description: The secretary of state expressed optimism that a shift could come within weeks now that the United States and other nations have agreed to a framework.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, with President François Hollande of France in Paris on Tuesday. Mr. Kerry said the Islamic State "will feel greater pressure" over the next few weeks.

item.title: U.S. Navy Ship, Bearing Message of Good Will, Docks in China
item.description: The commander of the United States Pacific Fleet met a Chinese vice admiral on board the destroyer as it began a weeklong port visit in Shanghai.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The Stethem, an American guided missile destroyer, arrived on Monday at the Wusong military port in northern Shanghai.

item.title: China in Mind, Obama Pledges Military Aid to Allies in Southeast Asia
item.description: The aid, $250 million over the next two years, is an effort to stand up to China’s increasingly aggressive claims on the South China Sea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi, Long a Symbol of Dignified Defiance, Sounds a Provocative Note
item.description: The leader of the National League for Democracy party in Myanmar has put reconciliation with the generals high on her agenda, but her words have become more audacious.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy opposition leader in Myanmar, arriving at Parliament in the capital, Naypyidaw, after general elections this month.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: France’s War Within
item.description: An embattled republic fights abroad, but also faces threats at home.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN
